revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox organization | name = Afghan Relief Organization (ARO) | logo = | type = Humanitarian aid and education | founded_date = 1998 | founder = Abdul Satar, Aboul Fazil Khalili | location = [[Cypress, California|Cypress]], [[Orange County, California]], [[United States|USA]] | origins = | key_people = | area_served = [[Afghanistan]] | focus = [[Humanitarian aid]], [[Education]] | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = [http://www.afghanrelief.org/ www.afghanrelief.org] | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''Afghanistan Relief Organization''' (ARO) is a [[Humanitarian aid|humanitarian]] organization which provides direct aid and education to those in need in [[Afghanistan]].<ref name="AfghanEmbassy">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = 12.10.2007 kite, Celebrities participate in Afghan kite auction for charity | publisher = ''The Embassy of Afghanistan, Washington DC, USA'' | date = 2007-12-10 | url = http://www.embassyofafghanistan.org/12.10.2007kite.html | accessdate = 2009-05-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090703085042/http://www.embassyofafghanistan.org/12.10.2007kite.html| archivedate= 3 July 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> It runs a large technology education centre in the Afghan capital, [[Kabul]],<ref name="LAWeekly" /> and is also involved in the training of [[Midwifery|midwives]].<ref name="VOAMidwives" />
==Description==
Afghanistan Relief Organization is a non-political, non-religious, nonprofit 501(c)(3), [[Non-governmental organization|non-governmental]] humanitarian organization, registered in both the [[United States]] and in Afghanistan, founded in the United States in 1998. It is based in [[Cypress, California|Cypress]], [[Orange County, California]], USA, and works in Afghanistan.<ref name="GuideStar">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = GuideStar JustGive Search: Afghanistan Relief (charity details) | publisher = ''[[GuideStar]]'' | date = | url = http://www.guidestar.org/pqShowGsReport.do?partner=justgive&ein=95-4822766 | accessdate = 2009-05-29}}</ref>
ARO was officially formed in 1998 by Abdul Satar, a communications project manager and businessman, and a fellow Afghan, Aboul Fazil Khalili, the grandson of the former Afghan poet laureate, [[Khalilullah Khalili]].<ref name="Khalili">{{cite web |last=Lynch |first=Stephen |title=Tulips in a Minefield |publisher=''[[The Orange County Register]] (reproduced on the AfghanRelief site)'' |date=2003-10-12 |url=http://www.afghanrelief.org/pdf/Lynch2003.pdf |accessdate=2009-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724225131/http://www.afghanrelief.org/pdf/Lynch2003.pdf |archivedate=24 July 2011 }}</ref> They wanted to help a region in the northern province of Takhar suffering after a crippling earthquake.<ref name="NCTimes">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = Escondido businessman looks to raise money for education | publisher = ''[[North County Times]]'' | date = 2008-04-25 | url = http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2007/02/21/news/inland/escondido/22007184309.txt | accessdate = 2009-05-28}}</ref><ref name="CNN">{{cite web |last=Staff |title=An Afghan-American Family's Unique Perspective (transcript) |publisher=''[[CNN]] Television, Sunday Morning'' |date=2008-04-25 |url=http://edition.cnn.hu/TRANSCRIPTS/0110/28/sm.18.html |accessdate=2009-05-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721104406/http://edition.cnn.hu/TRANSCRIPTS/0110/28/sm.18.html |archivedate=21 July 2011 }}</ref>
The organization delivers relief aid in the form of food, medicine, school supplies and winter relief supplies directly to those in need and offers general education programs designed to encourage self-sufficiency.<ref name="AfghanEmbassy" /> ARO provides free education to 1100 girls and boys, as well as providing adult education programs to both women and men at the Technology Education Center (TEC) in Kabul, where it employs Afghan staff.<ref name="LAWeekly">{{cite web |last=Marlow |first=Ann |title=Southern Californians build a terrific school in Kabul |publisher=''[[LA Weekly]] blogs (reproduced on ARO site)'' |date=October 2005 |url=http://www.afghanrelief.org/pdf/Marlowe2005.pdf |accessdate=2009-05-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724225510/http://www.afghanrelief.org/pdf/Marlowe2005.pdf |archivedate=24 July 2011 }} The text of the article is reproduced as a pdf on the ARO site, though the [http://laweekly.blogs.com/ann_marlowe_in_afghanista/2005/10/southern_califo.html original]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} on ''LA Weekly blogs'' is now unavailable. The title shows up in a Yahoo! search, where the '''cached file''' may be seen in full. Also partly available on the Way Back Machine (see discussion page). </ref><ref name="POM">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = Peace Operations Monitor: Overview of Non-Governmental Programs (Afghanistan) | publisher = ''Peace Operations Monitor'' | date = | url = http://pom.peacebuild.ca/NGOAfghanistan.shtml | accessdate = 2009-05-29}}</ref><ref name="AfghanEmbassy2" /> The centre operates from 7am to 7pm to accommodate the numbers.<ref name="GuideStar" /> Courses at the TEC include computing, [[Dari (Eastern Persian)|Dari]], [[Pashto language|Pashtu]], English, math, science, and job skills training.
ARO operates with an all-volunteer team and no paid office or warehouse space and with minimal overhead in the United States. The organization spends less than 7 percent on administration and fundraising in the United States and Afghanistan, and attempts to put the maximum percentage of donor contributions to work in Afghanistan.<ref name="AROFinance">{{cite web |last = Staff |title = ARO Annual IRS Form 990 Reports |publisher = ''Afghan Relief Organization'' |date = |url = http://www.afghanrelief.org/about-aro/financial-reports |accessdate = 2009-05-30 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090419005729/http://www.afghanrelief.org/about-aro/financial-reports |archivedate = 19 April 2009 |deadurl = yes |df = dmy-all }} All donations to ARO are tax deductible as allowable by IRS tax code.</ref>
Afghanistan Relief Organization is not to be confused with the original UK charity Afghan Relief, set up by the writer and Sufi teacher [[Idries Shah]] in 1984 and removed from the registry in 2002, having ceased operations.<ref name="AR">Afghan Relief was registered with the UK Charity Commission (no. 289910). It was founded 25 July 1984 and ceased to exist and was removed from the registry on 3 October 2002. See [http://www.charity-commission.gov.uk/ShowCharity/RegisterOfCharities/RemovedCharityMain.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=289910&SubsidiaryNumber=0 Charity Commission record]. It used the same Post Office box number in London as the Society for Sufi Studies for its [https://www.help.co.uk/charities/78343 address]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Activities==
===Aid supplies=== In February 2002, for the first time in almost 30 years, a commercial 747 aircraft landed at Kabul International Airport, carrying desperately needed humanitarian supplies for Afghanistan Relief.<ref name="UPI">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = Private U.S. relief plane lands in Kabul | publisher = ''Highbeam.com, originally from [[United Press International]]'' | date = 2002-02-12 | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-82788542.html | accessdate = 2009-05-28}}</ref><ref name="UPIFull">The ''United Press International'' article is reproduced in full on the AfghanRelief site [http://www.afghanrelief.org/about-aro/aro-relief-trips/february-2002 here] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724225153/http://www.afghanrelief.org/about-aro/aro-relief-trips/february-2002 |date=24 July 2011 }}</ref> Teaming up with two nonprofit organizations, [[Evergreen International Airlines]]' Evergreen Humanitarian and Relief Services Inc. and [[Mercy Corps]], and with the help of [[Microsoft]], $2 million worth of aid supplies, much of it collected by Afghanistan Relief Organization following an appeal, were shipped aboard the plane. Items included hygiene kits, newborn and baby kits, livestock feed, winter clothing and blankets, school kits, and medical supplies<ref name="Evergreen">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = Evergreen to ferry aid to Afghanistan | publisher = ''[[Evergreen International Airlines]]'' | date = 2002-01-24 | url = http://www.evergreenairlines.com/p_releases/12402.html | accessdate = 2009-05-28}}</ref><ref name="Evergreen2">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = Historic Humanitarian Flight Leaves for Kabul, Afghanistan | publisher = ''[[Mercy Corps]]'' | date = 2002-02-10 | url = http://www.mercycorps.org/aboutus/pressroom/10086 | accessdate = 2009-05-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090610143118/http://www.mercycorps.org/aboutus/pressroom/10086| archivedate= 10 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="Microsoft">{{cite web |last=Staff |title=Microsoft Assists Humanitarian Relief Flight to Afghanistan |publisher=''[[Microsoft]]'' |date=2002-02-15 |url=http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/features/2002/feb02/02-15evergreen.mspx |accessdate=2009-05-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070220045453/http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/features/2002/feb02/02-15evergreen.mspx |archivedate=20 February 2007 }}</ref>
At a meeting hosted by [[University of California, Los Angeles]]'s International Institute on 7 February 2002, Noor Delawari, an advisory board member of the Afghanistan Foundation and chair of the ARO, spoke of the urgent need for aid in Afghanistan: {{quotation|Half of the arable land has been destroyed. We had 2,000 miles of road; that is almost all gone. There are hundreds of thousands of orphan children. The mortality among the young people is unimaginable, dying of the cold weather. We must provide shelter for them. 8 million people were displaced over the last decade. We need to build 2 million new homes. We need to create a new security force. We need this to take care of the warlords or others who take advantage of the weakness of the social forces.<ref name="UCLA">{{cite web |last=Evans |first=Leslie |title=Engineers Make Plans to Reconstruct Afghanistan |publisher=''[[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] International Institute'' |date=2007-12-30 |url=http://www.international.ucla.edu/article.asp?parentid=1161 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030522043936/http://international.ucla.edu/article.asp?parentid=1161 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2003-05-22 |accessdate=2009-05-29 }}</ref>}}
===Education=== Afghanistan Relief Organization has also raised funds for the training of teachers and the construction of rural libraries in Afghanistan.<ref name="AfghanEmbassy2">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = 02.27 news aro, Ambassador Said T. Jawad Meets with the Afghan Community in Los Angeles | publisher = ''The Embassy of Afghanistan, Washington DC, USA'' | date = 2007-02-27 | url = http://www.embassyofafghanistan.org/02.27newsaro.html | accessdate = 2009-05-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090703071041/http://www.embassyofafghanistan.org/02.27newsaro.html| archivedate= 3 July 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="AfghanReliefAbout">{{cite web |last = Staff |title = ARO Facts -- Afghanistan Relief Organization |publisher = ''Afghanistan Relief Organization'' |date = |url = http://www.afghanrelief.org/about-afghanistan/about-aro/aro-facts |accessdate = 2009-05-28 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090504212314/http://www.afghanrelief.org/about-afghanistan/about-aro/aro-facts |archivedate = 4 May 2009 |deadurl = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> The fundraising events have been supported by many celebrities, including [[Halle Berry]], former President [[George H. W. Bush]], [[Cher]], [[Will Ferrell]], [[Jodie Foster]], [[Jake Gyllenhaal]], ''[[Kite Runner]]'' author [[Khaled Hosseini]], [[Angelina Jolie]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Eva Mendes]], Steve Nash and [[Natalie Portman]].<ref name="AfghanEmbassy" /><ref name="PRNewsWire">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = Madonna, Angelina Jolie, Will Ferrell, Cher, Steve Nash, Former President George... | publisher = ''[[PR Newswire]] via [[Reuters]]'' | date = 2007-12-03 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS214098+03-Dec-2007+PRN20071203 | accessdate = 2009-05-28}}</ref><ref name="OCReg">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = Fundraiser offers aid to Afghans | publisher = ''[[The Orange County Register]]'' | date = 2006-02-28 | url = http://www.ocregister.com/ocregister/life/columns/article_1019963.php | accessdate = 2009-05-28}}</ref>
Afghan Ambassador [[Said Tayeb Jawad]] visited [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] on 23 February 2007 to deliver the keynote address at the ARO's annual fundraiser, ''Peace Through Education''.<ref name="AfghanEmbassy2" />
According to a [[United Nations Children's Fund]] (UNICEF) Education Fact Sheet (plus Q and A) for Afghanistan, 2007: {{quotation|Afghanistan has one the highest proportion of school-age (7-12) children in the world: about 1 in 5 Afghans is a primary school-age child. Despite success in sending children to school, trends in gender disparity in education remains worrisome. For instance, the literary rate for young women (aged 15-24) is only 18 per cent, compared to 50 per cent for boys. The primary school completion rate for boys is 32 per cent versus 13 per cent for girls. In terms of cohort tracking, only 30 percent of girls (age 12 years) reach Grade 5, compared to 56 per cent for boys. (Source: Best Estimates of Social Indicators for children in Afghanistan, 1990-2005).<ref name="UNICEF">{{cite web |last=Staff |title=UNICEF Education Fact Sheet for Afghanistan |publisher=''[[United Nations Children's Fund]] (reproduced on [[ReliefWeb]] site)'' |year=2007 |url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/RWFiles2008.nsf/FilesByRWDocUnidFilename/EGUA-7C6MM6-full_report.pdf/$File/full_report.pdf |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20080314103529/http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/RWFiles2008.nsf/FilesByRWDocUnidFilename/EGUA-7C6MM6-full_report.pdf/$File/full_report.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-03-14 |accessdate=2009-05-29 }}</ref>}}
Film producers [[Participant Productions]] and [[Paramount Vantage]] have designated ARO as one of the non-governmental organization (NGO) partners in a social action campaign to accompany the award-winning film, ''[[The Kite Runner (film)|The Kite Runner]]'', based on Khaled Hosseini's international best-seller, through an introduction by the author.<ref name="AROKiteRunner">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = The Kite Runner -- Afghanistan Relief Organization | publisher = ''Afghanistan Relief Organization'' | date = | url = http://www.afghanrelief.org/aro-projects/the-kite-runner | accessdate = 2009-05-28}}</ref>
In 2007, Paramount Classics and [[DreamWorks]] Pictures studios donated 500 laptop computers to schoolchildren in Kabul. The ARO distributed the computers, provided by the [[One Laptop per Child]] initiative which is aimed at children in developing countries.<ref name="SFC">{{cite web | last = Hart | first = Hugh | title = Industry Buzz | publisher = ''SFGate: Home of the [[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' | date = 2007-12-30 | url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/12/30/PKIVU255S.DTL | accessdate = 2009-05-29}}</ref> ''Kite Runner'' author Khaled Hosseini is quoted as saying that "Education of the general population is critical to the transformation of Afghanistan's political and economic condition."<ref name="ReutersLaptop">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = The Kite Runner Inspires Gift Through One Laptop | publisher = ''[[Reuters]]'' | date = 2007-12-12 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/sphereNews/idUS146828+12-Dec-2007+PRN20071212?sp=true&view=sphere | accessdate = 2009-05-29}}</ref>
===Midwifery training=== With deaths in pregnancy or in childbirth so high in Afghanistan, and few trained women there to assist with childbirth, the training of midwives is another major project for the Afghanistan Relief Organization.<ref name="VOAMidwives">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = Development Report - Midwives in Training | publisher = ''[[Voice of America]]'' | date = 2004-05-09 | url = http://www.voanews.com/specialenglish/archive/2004-05/a-2004-05-09-2-1.cfm | accessdate = 2009-05-29}}</ref> In 2006, one in 60 Afghan women died of pregnancy-related causes, giving the country one of the world's highest maternal mortality rates, second only to Sierra Leone. The infant mortality rate was about 135 per 1,000 live births in 2006, which is an improvement from the 165 per 1,000 in 2001, but is still far too high.<ref name="AfghanEmbassyMidwives">{{cite web | last = Staff | title = Study Finds Public Health Improving as Afghans Celebrate International Midwives' Day | publisher = ''The Embassy of Afghanistan, Washington DC, USA'' | date = 2007-05-16 | url = http://www.embassyofafghanistan.org/05.16newsjohnhopkinsstudy.html | accessdate = 2009-05-29| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090703085418/http://www.embassyofafghanistan.org/05.16newsjohnhopkinsstudy.html| archivedate= 3 July 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Humanitarian aid]]

{{Orphan|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist |genre = [[Música clásica|Clásico]] |background = non_vocal_instrumentalist |image = Alba Herrera y Ogazón.jpg |instrument = [[Piano]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1885|2|2|df=y}} |death_date = {{death year and age|1931|1885}} |name = Alba Herrera y Ogazón |occupation = [[Pianist]]a
[[Escritora]]
[[Profesora]]
[[Musicóloga]]
[[Periodista]] |origin = {{flagicon|Mexico}} [[Ciudad de México]], [[México]]. }} '''Alba Herrera y Ogazón''' ([[Mexico City]], 2 February 1885 - 1931), a Mexican [[pianist]], [[writer]],http://www.acanomas.com/Diccionario-Espanol/94851/HERRERA-Y-OGAZON,-Alba---(1885-1931).htm [[journalist]], [[teacher]] she's considered the first female [[musicologist]].{{cite news|last=|first=|title=Revaloran legado de la primera musicóloga de México|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/cultura/2013/musica-critica-musicologia-alba-herrera-y-ogazon-962997.html|date=|accessdate=7 March 2017|work=El Universal|page=|language=}} ==Biography== Alba started studying the piano in a young age, with her elder brother, and that defined her Profession. She continued to learn the piano and she was able to perform very complex compositions compared to her age, which made her a special piano player. Alba went to "The English school of Mrs. Miller" and then to the "French School of Mlle. Edges"; she continued her studies in English and French with the help of her father; she showed interest in literature of different writers, specially [[William Shakespeare]]. After completing her higher education, she continued her piano studies with the maestro [[Carlos J. Meneses]] who presented her in some recitals. When the master Meneses returned to the National Conservatory, from which it had separated previously, Alba enrolled in the conservatory as well, and continued her classes with him. She also attended the classes of [[Alberto Villaseñor]], her cousin Pedro Luis Ogazon and [[Ricardo Castro]] who was the Directorate of the Conservatory at that time. [[Ricardo Castro]] frequently changed the piano teachers because of circumstances beyond his control, but this did not prejudice Alba's ability to carry out her studies. At the end of her piano career at the National Conservatory of Music in 1908, she traveled to New York City and obtained the "B certificate" from the 'Virgil Academy' and she received congratulations from her teacher, Mr. [[A. K. Virgil]]. Considering herself apt to instruct her compatriots, she began teaching music and piano shortly after her return to Mexico following the 'Virgil System'. In 1910, during his second visit to Mexico, [[Josef Hofmann]] asked Alba to translate his book "La Execución Pianística", a task that she subsequently carried out. Without abandoning the musical-pianist art, in 1917, she published her book "The Musical Art in Mexico", in which she summarized the musical movement in Mexico until that year. Later she carried out diverse concerts, some with the National Classic Quartet and others. In 1919, for the first time in Mexico, Alba Herrera y Ogazón with [[Julian Carrillo]] played the "Sonatas of Beethoven". Later she undertook a tour in the republic in company with [[Julián Carrillo]] the director of the National Symphony Orchestra, and Sante Lo Priore, an Italian violinist. After she finished her tour in the republic, she published her book "Points of View", that consisted of critic essays in music; the book was circulated in 1921. She then started the preparation of several other books: ''Mosaicos Musicales'', ''Greorge Eliot'', ''My Miserable Hours'' and ''General History of Music''. As a lecturer Alba Herrera y Ogazón participated effectively in the celebration of the centenary of [[Ludwig van Beethoven|Beethoven]], in the conference that was dictated to music, during the time of the romanticism; and was a speaker in the speeches of the inauguration of the Faculty of Music and anniversary, also she taught classes of musical history.{{cite web|url=http://www.cenart.gob.mx/centros/cenidim/publicaciones_tipo.htm|title=Centro Nacional de Investigación, Documentación e Información Musical - Cenidim|accessdate=7 March 2017|author=|authorlink=|date=7 April 2013|language=|website=|publisher=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130407232327/http://www.cenart.gob.mx/centros/cenidim/publicaciones_tipo.htm|archivedate=7 April 2013}} As a journalist, Alba collaborated actively with the Time, The Illustrated World, The Journal, The Tribune, Magazine of Magazines, Pegasus, El Globo, El Universal Ilustrado, El Universal, and others. She also occasionally collaborated with "Excélsior", "Get to Know Mexico", "La Opinión", "Mexican Herald", "Conservatorio", "Tricolor" Sombra "," Cosmos "," New Democracy "(New York) etc., and she was a member of following corporations: [[Ateneo de la Juventud Mexicana|Ateneo de México]] , Society of Local History Studies of Mexico City, Ateneo Hispánico, PEN Grupo Ariel, Sociedad Pro Arte Patrio, International League of Iberian and Hispanic American Women, and the International Society of Pianoforte Teachers and Players, also held the following positions: lecturer in the former department of aesthetic culture of the Secretariat of Public Education (Mexico), during 1922 to 1927; professor of piano and history of the music, in the National Conservatory and in the faculty of music of the National University of Mexico, independent until its death. Alba Herrera y Ogazon died in 1931. She spent her last days writing. ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Herrera, Alba}} [[Category:Mexican pianists]] [[Category:Mexican women pianists]] [[Category:Mexican journalists]] [[Category:Music educators]] [[Category:1885 births]] [[Category:1931 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century women musicians]]

page.title: Alexander Hamilton Institute for the Study of Western Civilization

revision.text:
{{about|the institute in Clinton, New York|the former institute for business education in New York City|Alexander Hamilton Institute}} {{notability|Organizations|date=January 2015}} '''Alexander Hamilton Institute for the Study of Western Civilization''' is an educational institute in [[Clinton, Oneida County, New York|Clinton, New York]] founded in 2007.<ref>[http://theahi.org/ Alexander Hamilton Institute] website. Accessed 14.01.2015.</ref> Judge [[David Aldrich Nelson]] was a charter director.<ref>Grant Segall, [http://www.cleveland.com/obituaries/index.ssf/2010/10/us_appeals_judge_david_aldrich.html "U.S. Appeals Judge David Aldrich Nelson started his legal career in Cleveland"], ''[[The Plain Dealer]]'', October 7, 2010.</ref> One of its board members is [[Jane Fraser (philanthropy)|Jane Fraser]].<ref name="theahi1">{{cite web|url=http://www.theahi.org/board-of-directors/ |title=Board of Directors |publisher=The AHI |date= |accessdate=2013-08-10}}</ref>
== History == History professor [[Robert L. Paquette]] of [[Hamilton College (New York)|Hamilton College]] in Clinton had led an attempt to create an "Alexander Hamilton Center" on the Hamilton College campus, but it was unsuccessful.<ref>"[http://hcagr.squarespace.com/home/2006/11/29/the-failure-of-the-alexander-hamilton-center.html The failure of the Alexander Hamilton Center]," at hcagr.squarespace.com January 9, 2007.</ref><ref>"Rejected by NY college, conservative center sets up off campus", ''Higher Education News'', 18 September 2007</ref> A faculty vote voiced concern that the proposal to establish this alumni-financed center to study "capitalism, natural law and the role of religion in politics" would have an overt conservative political tendency and would not be subject to sufficient oversight by the school. The college's decision not to proceed drew criticism from conservative commentators,<ref>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-158523022.html "Hamilton Capitulates"], ''[[The New Criterion]]'', January 1, 2007 {{subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}} (opinion).</ref><ref>Katherine Mangu-Ward, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB116917079496581026 "The New Campus Dissidents"], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', January 19, 2007 {{subscription required}} (opinion).</ref> and the institute was established as an off-campus, independent entity.<ref>Patricia Cohen, [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/22/education/22conservative.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 "Conservatives Try New Tack on Campuses"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 21, 2008.</ref>
== People == People affiliated with the Alexander Hamilton Institute: * David B. Frisk, Resident Fellow.<ref>Maxmillian Angerholzer III, James Kitfield, Christopher P. Lu (2014) ''Triumphs and Tragedies of the Modern Congress.'' p. 387</ref> * [[Jane Fraser (philanthropy)|Jane Fraser]], one of its board members.<ref name="theahi1"/> * [[David Aldrich Nelson]] (1932–2010), its first director. * David K. Nichols, senior fellow<ref>Robert Maranto, Fredrick Hess, Richard Redding (2009). ''The Politically Correct University.'' p. 247</ref> * Mary P. Nichols, senior fellow<ref>Mary P. Nichols. ''Socrates on Friendship and Community: Reflections on Plato's Symposium.'' (2009), p. i</ref> * [[Robert L. Paquette]], cofounder and fellow * [[Juliana Geran Pilon]], Senior Fellow.<ref name="exp">[https://www.julianapilon.com/experience Juliana Geran Pilon: Experience]</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://theahi.org/ Alexander Hamilton Institute] website
[[Category:2007 establishments in New York (state)]]
{{edu-org-stub}}

The '''Andrew Lang Lecture''' series is held at the [[University of St. Andrews]]. The lectures are named after [[Andrew Lang]]. The most famous lecture in this series is that given by [[J. R. R. Tolkien]] in March 1939, entitled 'Fairy Stories', but published subsequently as '[[On Fairy-Stories]]'.
==Lectures== * December 1927 – 'Andrew Lang', by George Gordon. * 1928 – 'Andrew Lang's work for Homer', by Alexander Shewan. * 1929 – 'The raw material of religion', by R. R. Marett. * 1930 – 'Andrew Lang as historian', by [[Robert Rait|Robert S. Rait]]. * 1931 – 'Andrew Lang and the Maid of France', by [[Louis Cazamian]] * 1932 – 'Andrew Lang and the Border', by [[John Buchan]] (Lord Tweedsmuir). * 6 December 1933 – 'Lang, Lockhart and biography', by H.J.C. Grierson. * 21 November 1934 – 'Andrew Lang and the House of Stuart', by John Duncan. * 1937 – 'Andrew Lang's poetry', by A. Blyth Webster. * 8 March 1939 – '[[On Fairy-Stories]]', by [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://calvin.st-andrews.ac.uk/external_relations/news_article.cfm?reference%3D610 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-04-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310224433/http://calvin.st-andrews.ac.uk/external_relations/news_article.cfm?reference=610 |archivedate=2007-03-10 |df= }}</ref> * 7 May 1947 – 'Andrew Lang the poet', by [[Gilbert Murray]]. * 5 April 1948 – 'Law and custom', by Hugh Pattisan MacMillan, Baron MacMillan. * 11 May 1949 – 'Andrew Lang and the casket letter controversy' by J. B. Black. * 11 May 1950 – 'Andrew Lang and journalism', by J. B. Salmond * 25 April 1951 – 'Andrew Lang : his place in anthropology', by Herbert J. Rose. * 14 November 1951 – 'Andrew Lang, [[John Knox]] and Scottish Presbyterianism', by William Croft Dickinson. * 16 February 1955 – 'Homer and his forerunners', by [[Maurice Bowra]]. * 14 November 1956 – 'Shakespeare's Scotland', by James Fergusson. * 8 February 1978 – 'The writing of Scottish history in the time of Andrew Lang', R.G. Cant. * 26 January 1988 – 'The Scottish paradox' by [[Gordon Wilson (Scottish politician)|Gordon Wilson]] * 29 April 2004 – 'Hamlet and the Tables of Memory' by Peter Stallybrass <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/~www_se/Stallybrass.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-04-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070313063913/http://www.st-andrews.ac.uk/~www_se/Stallybrass.html |archivedate=2007-03-13 |df= }}</ref> * 1 November 2012 – 'Folklore versus Fakelore: An Imagined Conversation with Andrew Lang' by [[Jane Yolen]], the first woman to give the Andrew Lang lecture <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfscope.com/2012/09/jane-yolen-to-lecture-at-st-andrews/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-24 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017020735/http://www.sfscope.com/2012/09/jane-yolen-to-lecture-at-st-andrews/ |archivedate=2015-10-17 |df= }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/underwire/2013/01/geeks-guide-jane-yolen/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140315071915/http://www.wired.com/underwire/2013/01/geeks-guide-jane-yolen |archivedate=2014-03-15 |df= }}</ref> * 31 October 2017 - " Andrew Lang and the Folkloristic Legacy of 'The Forest'" by [[Lizanne Henderson]], 90th Anniversary Lecture
==References== *[http://138.251.116.3/search/ University of St. Andrews Library catalogue]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{reflist}}
[[Category:Lecture series|Lang]] [[Category:University of St Andrews]]

revision.comment: ([[c:GR|GR]]) [[c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: [[File:Pasater templom.jpg]] → [[File:Pasaréti téri templom.jpg]] mistyped title
revision.text:
{{improveref|date=January 2017}}
[[Image:Budapest districts.png|right|thumb|The District Map of Budapest]]
'''[[Bauhaus]]''' was a dominant architectural tendency in [[Budapest]], the capital of [[Hungary]], between 1930 and 1948. Large residential buildings, cinemas, churches and even an airport was built in this style, in particular in [[Újlipótváros]] in the XIII district, and [[Városmajor]] and [[Pasarét]] in the II district of the city.
==Pasarét== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:The 1931 Bauhaus exhibition street.jpg|thumb|left|300px|The 1931 Bauhaus exhibition street Architects: various, like Lajos Kozma and József Fischer]] --> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:The 1931 Bauhaus exhibition street 2.jpg|thumb|right|150px|The 1931 Bauhaus exhibition street Architects: various, like Lajos Kozma and József Fischer]] --> *Villas in Napraforgó utca (District 2, Napraforgó utca 1-22).<ref name="Napraforgó utca">{{cite web|url=http://architectuul.com/architecture/napraforgo-street-1|title=Napraforgó utca|publisher=Architectuul|accessdate=2011-11-11|last=|first=}}</ref> In 1931, some representatives of the modern architecture style made a proposal to the Budapest Public Works Council to have a whole street designed by the best architects, based on an example in Stuttgart. The plan was implemented one year later. In spite of using small sites, an enthusiastic builder devoted to modern architecture carried out the outstanding plans in a magnificent way. There is a small square in the middle of the street, where a stone displays the names of all architects involved. There are altogether 22 villas, with a creek called Devil’s Trench on one side. Although some of the houses have been rebuilt since then, the original character was maintained nearly everywhere.
Google Maps [http://maps.google.de/maps?f=l&hl=de&q=Napraforg%C3%B3+utca&ie=UTF8&near=&z=17&ll=47.527206,18.9868&spn=0.004818,0.009559&t=h&om=1]. Public transport: Bus No. 5.
*Villa with two-storey flats, Lotz Károly utca 4/b. The villa was built in 1933, and the architect decided to apply the two-storey arrangement in order to increase the garden area. The building was designed by Farkas Molnár, an internationally renowned Hungarian master of Bauhaus. *Villa with variable walls at Harangvirág utca 11. The variable walls enable the residents to create a 100-squaremeter area inside the flats. *Special villa at Pasaréti út 97. It is a multi-storey building that fits very well with the garden. It was extended in the 70s, maintaining the original idea. *Villa at Orsó utca 21. It is a building with a roof terrace. It was built on a narrow, sloping site. The architect was Lajos Kozma. *Residential building at Trombitás utca 32. It seems as if several villas had been built into one, the chessboard like facade allows for a complete separation. *Roman Catholic Church and monastery in Pasaréti tér. It was built in the centre of the quarter in 1933, according to the solemn and simple plan of Gyula Rimanóczy.
{{Clear}}
==Bauhaus 1933 floor plan== Round [[Stairway|Staircase]] and other typical [[Bauhaus]] construction elements, Bauhaus [[Proportion (architecture)|proportions]], on this original [[Floor plan]] from August 1933 in [[Budapest]].
[[Image:Budapest-August-1933-Bauhaus.jpg|thumb|left|200px|detail from Bauhaus [[Floor plan]] August 1933 in Budapest]]
[[Image:Budapest-1933-Staircase.jpg|thumb|right|200px|detail Bauhaus Staircase, August 1933 in Budapest]]
{{Clear}}
==Újlipótváros, Szent István park (St. Stephen’s Park) and Margit körút== [[Image:Margitsziget-1888-Meyers-Lexikon.jpg|thumb|left|180px|1888 - the Bridge was not connected to Margaret Island, Ujlipótváros streets projected]] <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Retirement house Manfréd Weiss 1938.jpg|thumb|right|400px|Retirement house Manfréd Weiss (1938) Architects: Béla Hofstätter & Ferenc (Margit körút 15-17)]] --> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Staircase inside the Retirement house Manfréd Weiss (1938).jpg|thumb|right|180px|Staircase inside the Retirement house Manfréd Weiss (1938) Architects: Béla Hofstätter & Ferenc (Margit körút 15-17)]] -->
Szent István park (St. Stephen’s Park) (XIII., between the River Danube and Hollán Ernő utca).
This area lies to the North of Margit Bridge and was built in the 1930 with breathtaking speed, along Pozsonyi út. The most scenic place of the whole area is St. Stephen’s Park, part of which has a view on the river, with huge and envied roof terraces. The houses are 25 meters tall, they are all six-storey buildings. Their design and construction began in 1928, on an area of 33,000 square meters.
Most of the houses on that square were designed by Béla Hofstätter and Ferenc Domány. Public transport: Jászai Mari tér: Tram No. 4/6, Tram No. 2. On the Google Maps [http://maps.google.de/maps?f=l&hl=de&q=Napraforg%C3%B3+utca&ie=UTF8&near=&om=1&z=17&ll=47.518259,19.05246&spn=0.004818,0.009559&t=h].
*Pozsonyi út 53-55. An interesting building with shops, standing on a triangle-shaped site at the corner of Wahrmann Mór köz. *Budapest Pozsonyi Street Protestant Church (Pozsonyi út 58.) A church and a belfry in modern style with classicist streaks. It was opened in 1940. *Dunapark House. Pozsonyi út 38-42. A complex of two luxury houses. A cinema was planned to be built between the two houses, but it was not implemented eventually. However, the area of the café increased this way. *Residential building at Pozsonyi út 33/a. Its unique features are a foyer with an arched wall, standing in a 45 degree angle with the entrance, as well as an elegant doorway. *Residential building at Tátra utca 5/c. It has especially large balconies, which run all the way along the facade. It also has asymmetric shop facilities. *Residential building at Pozsonyi út 19. A corner house with a variable facade and interesting arched balconies on the corner.
{{Clear}}
==Pasarét Church and Heart of Jesus Church in Városmajor==
[[Image:Pasaréti téri templom.jpg|left|thumb|200px|Pasaret church, plan of Gyula Rimanóczy]]
*Roman Catholic Church and monastery in Pasaréti tér. It was built in the centre of the quarter in 1933, according to the solemn and simple plan of [[Gyula Rimanóczy]]. *Heart of Jesus Church in Városmajor (XII., 5 Csaba utca) [[Bertalan Arkay|Bertalan Árkay]]’s Városmajor Church and its belfry (1933-1937) form an outstanding piece of art of the era between the two wars as well as of the history of Hungarian church architecture in general. Public transport: take Underground Line 2 or Tram No. 4/6 to Moszkva tér. {{clear}}
==Bauhaus in Budapest about 1930== <gallery> Image:Budapest-Napraforgo-u-CIMG1787.jpg Image:Budapest -Lotz-Karoly-4b-CIMG1811.jpg Image:Budapest-Harangvirag-u-CIMG1802.jpg Image:Budapest-Napraforgo-u-CIMG1784.jpg|Settlement initiated 1932 after the [[Great Depression]] Image:Budapest-Napraforgo-u-CIMG1791.jpg Image:Budapest-Orso-u-CIMG1797.jpg Image:Budapest-Lotz-Karoly-u-CIMG1810.jpg Image:Budapest-Pasareti-u-97-CIMG1806.jpg Image:Budapest-Pasareti-u-97-CIMG1804.jpg Image:Budapest-Napraforbo-u-CIMG1779.jpg Image:Budapest-Napraforgo-u-CIMG1782.jpg Image:Budapest-Napraforgo-u-CIMG1783.jpg Image:Budapest-Napraforgo-u-11-az-emlekko-felol-nezve-CIMG1785.jpg Image:Budapest-Napraforgo-u-CIMG1786.jpg Image:Budapest-Napraforgo-u-CIMG1788.jpg Image:Budapest-Napraforgo-u-CIMG1789.jpg Image:Budapest-Orso-u-Imre-Nagy-home-CIMG1796.jpg|[[Imre Nagy]]'s home Image:Budapest-Orso-u-Imre-Nagy-Home-CIMG1795.jpg|Imre Nagy's home Image:Budapest-Pasareti-u-Museum-Park-CIMG1794.jpg Image:Budapest-Pasareti-u-Museum-Prk-CIMG1792.jpg </gallery>
===Bauhaus on the Killesberg in Stuttgart, Germany=== The [[Weissenhof Estate]], which was built on the Killesberg in Stuttgart in 1927, is one of the best examples for the art of the "new architecture" in Germany. Within no more than 21 weeks, 21 houses containing 63 flats were constructed. The settlement is not an organically grown structure, it is part of the exhibition "Die Wohnung" ("The flat") organised by the German Werkbund in 1927. In [[World War II]] 11 of the 21 houses destroyed. The Bauhaus exhibition street in [[Budapest]], 22 villas in the Napraforgó utca [[Pasarét]] based on the example in Stuttgart.
The international reputation of the Weißenhofsiedlung and its architects brings it 30 000 visitors per year.
[https://web.archive.org/web/20070212213353/http://www.weissenhof.ckom.de/01_allgemein/index.php?lang=en More details on the example in Stuttgart]
==See also== *[[Újlipótváros]] *[[Pasarét]]
==Sources, external information== {{Commons|Bauhaus}} *[http://architectuul.com/architecture/napraforgo-street-1 Bauhaus in Budapest - Napraforgó Street Experimental Housing ] *Bauhaus in Budapest [https://www.flickr.com/search/?q=Bauhaus&w=25752084%40N00] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061211055328/http://www.mie.hu/index.php?set_lang=en Moholy-Nagy University of Art and Design Budapest] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070128130116/http://www.moholy-nagy.org/Statement.html The Moholy-Nagy Foundation] *Molnár Farkas houses [https://www.flickr.com/photos/53985463@N00/sets/72157594178266003/] *Molnár Farkas c.v. (Hungarian) [http://www.bibl.u-szeged.hu/ha/muveszet/epiteszet/molnar.html] *[http://www.busgo.hu/varosnezo/bauhaus.html Bauhaus sights] {{de icon}}
===Modern architecture in Budapest (photographs)=== *Budapest XI., Szent Adalbert tér 12. / Architect: HENNY Ferenc [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927174823/http://budapestmodern.org/index.php?showimage=23] *Budapest 12th District Hall / Architect: HENNY Ferenc [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927174811/http://budapestmodern.org/index.php?showimage=24] *Saint Anthony of Padua Church / Architect: RIMANÓCZY Gyula [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927174817/http://budapestmodern.org/index.php?showimage=26] *Szeged, Berzsenyi u. 2/b (1932)/ Architect: MOLNÁR Farkas [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927174805/http://budapestmodern.org/index.php?showimage=27]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Culture in Budapest]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Budapest]] [[Category:History of Budapest]] [[Category:Architecture schools]] [[Category:Bauhaus|Budapest]] [[Category:Modernist architecture]]

{{Short description|American painter}} {{Infobox artist | name = Benny Andrews | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1930|11|13}} | birth_place = [[Plainview, Georgia|Plainview]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2006|11|10|1930|11|13}} | death_place = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | nationality = {{flagicon|USA}} American | field = | training = [[Art Institute of Chicago#The School|School of the Art Institute of Chicago]] | movement = [[Expressionism|expressionist]] style, [[Surrealism]] and Southern [[folk art]] | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = }}
'''Benny Andrews''' (November 13, 1930 – November 10, 2006) was an African-American [[Painting|painter]], [[Printmaking|printmaker]], and creator of [[collage]]s. During the 1950s, he studied at the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago]], where he began to take an interest in painting. In 1958, he moved to New York City to pursue artistic and activist work. Among other successes, he created art education programs to serve underprivileged students at [[Queens College]] and participated actively in the [[Black Emergency Cultural Coalition]] (1969). His advocacy of artists of color [[Howardena Pindell]], [[Sam Gilliam]], [[Roy DeCarava]], and others contributed to their increasing visibility and reputation in museums and the historical canon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bennyandrews.com/|title=Home - Overview|last=|first=|date=|website=Benny Andrews Estate|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=March 10, 2018}}</ref> He received many awards, including the [[John Hay Whitney]] Fellowship (1965–66), the [[New York Council on the Arts]] fellowships (1971–81), and the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] Fellowship (1974–81).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.encyclopedia.com/people/history/historians-miscellaneous-biographies/benny-andrews|title=Andrews, Benny, 1930-|last=|first=|date=2005|website=Contemporary Black Biography. Encyclopedia.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=March 10, 2018}}</ref>
==Background== Benny Andrews was born into a family of ten on November 13, 1930, in the small community of [[Plainview, Georgia]]. His parents, George and Viola (née Perryman), were sharecroppers.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/12/nyregion/12andrews.html|title=Benny Andrews, 75, Dies; Painted Life in the South|last=Genocchio|first=Benjamin|date=2006-11-12|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-07|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> His mother and father emphasized the importance of education, religion, and freedom of expression. [[George Andrews (artist)|George Andrews]] himself was a self-taught artist whose drawings and paintings led to renown as the "Dot Man" and a retrospective at the [[Morris Museum of Art]].
Despite his parents' stress on education, they could not afford to let Andrews go to school when they needed his help to pick or plant cotton. He attended high school only in the winter.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.encyclopedia.com/people/history/historians-miscellaneous-biographies/benny-andrews|title=Benny Andrews facts, information, pictures|last=|first=|date=|website=Encyclopedia.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-07}}</ref> Andrews managed to graduate from Burney Street High School in Madison, Georgia in 1948, making him his family's first high school graduate.
He got a two-year scholarship to go to [[Forth Valley College]], whose limited art curriculum made it difficult for him to explore a range of media. His grades were poor, so when his scholarship ran out, he left college to join the [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]].<ref name=":1" /> Having served from 1950 to 1953, he used the [[G.I. Bill]] to attend the [[Art Institute of Chicago#The School|School of the Art Institute of Chicago]], where he was trained as an [[abstract expressionist]] <ref name=":1" /> and received his [[Bachelor of Fine Arts|BFA]].
In 1962 the ''New York Times'' praised his first New York City solo exhibit.<ref name=":1" /> He received the John Hay Whitney Fellowship for 1965-1966 and a CAPS award from the [[New York State Council on the Arts]] in 1971.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oxfordartonline.com|title=Benny Andrews|last=Cullen|first=Deborah|date=|website=Grove Art Online. Oxford Art Online|publisher=Oxford University Press|access-date=28 January 2017}}</ref> In the same year, he painted one of his most notable works, ''No More Games'', which highlighted the plight of black artists and became an icon of his emerging [[social justice]] activism in the art world.<ref>{{Cite book|title="Benny Andrews," St. James Guide to Black Artists, Thomas Riggs, ed.|last=Tenabe|first=Gabriel|publisher=St. James Press|year=1997|isbn=1558622209|location=Detroit|pages=16|quote=|via=}}</ref>
From 1968 to 1997, Andrews taught at [[Queens College, City University of New York]] and created an arts program for prisons, one that became a national model.
==Social justice work== In 1969, Andrews co-founded the Black Emergency Cultural Coalition (BECC), an organization that protested the ''[[Harlem on My Mind protest|Harlem on My Mind: Cultural Capital of Black America, 1900-1968]]'' exhibit at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]. No African-Americans had been involved in organizing the show, and it contained no art—only photo reproductions and copies of newspaper articles about Harlem.
The BECC then persuaded the [[Whitney Museum of American Art|Whitney Museum]] to launch a similar exhibition of African American artists, but later felt compelled to boycott the Whitney show for similar reasons.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/benny-andrews Benny Andrews: Biography and Much More from Answers.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
From 1982 to 1984, Andrews served as the director of visual arts for the [[National Endowment for the Arts]]. In this position, he had the chance to advocate for fellowships and grants to go to talented black artists who may otherwise have escaped notice.
Andrews traveled in 2006 to the [[Gulf Coast of the United States|Gulf Coast]] to work on an art project with children displaced by [[Hurricane Katrina]].<ref>[http://www.newyorktimes/2006/Benny Andrews, 75, Dies; Painted Life in the South]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Art== Benny Andrews was a [[Figure painting|figural painter]] in the [[Expressionism|expressionist]] style who painted a diverse range of themes of suffering and injustice, including the [[Holocaust]], [[Indian Removal|Native American forced migrations]], and [[Hurricane Katrina]]. In the 1960s he began to find his own style of painting, which developed parallel to the flourishing [[collage]] moment.<ref name=":0" /> Other influences on his work include [[surrealism]] and Southern [[folk art]]. His work hangs in the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York City; the [[Art Institute of Chicago]]; the [[Studio Museum in Harlem|Studio Museum]] in [[Harlem]] (New York City); the [[High Museum of Art]] in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]; the [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden|Hirshhorn Museum]] in Washington, DC; and the [[Ogden Museum of Southern Art]] in [[New Orleans, Louisiana]].
Reflecting his [[minimalism|minimalist]] style, Andrews said he was not interested in how much he could paint, but how little. He incorporated his sparing use of geometrical forms to convey broader messages about his subjects. Gabriel Tenabe describes his drawing as "delicate, subtle, and intimate... draw(ing) from his past private life in Georgia and his social life in New York." [[Christian symbolism|Christian imagery]] is juxtaposed with sensibilities of [[humanism]] to call out false religion, false democracy, [[sexism]], and [[militarism]] and their roles in creating a failed society.<ref name=":0" />
Using various media, Andrews depicted diverse American scenes and people in a figurative style that he felt both reflected the dignity of those he portrayed and served his commitment to social change.
==Family life== Benny Andrews was married to artist [[Nene Humphrey]] for 20 years. He had three children.
Andrews died of cancer at the age of 75.
==Selected Collections== * [[Minneapolis Institute of Art]], Minneapolis, MN
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/12/nyregion/12andrews.html New York Times obituary] * [http://www.aaa.si.edu/collections/benny-andrews-papers-7006 Benny Andrews papers, 1945–1968] from the Smithsonian [[Archives of American Art]] * {{LCAuth|n50022499|Benny Andrews|26|}} * Benny Andrews at the [https://collections.artsmia.org/search/Benny%20Andrews Minneapolis Institute of Art, Minneapolis, MN] * [http://pid.emory.edu/ark:/25593/8xxcf Benny Andrews papers, 1940-2006] from the [https://rose.library.emory.edu/ Stuart A. Rose Library, Emory University] {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Andrews, Benny}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American painters]] [[Category:American male painters]] [[Category:21st-century American painters]] [[Category:American Expressionist painters]] [[Category:Art educators]] [[Category:American educators]] [[Category:African-American artists]] [[Category:School of the Art Institute of Chicago alumni]] [[Category:Queens College, City University of New York faculty]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in New York (state)]] [[Category:People from Morgan County, Georgia]] [[Category:Painters from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:20th-century American printmakers]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} <!--Per Wikipedia:Manual of style, use she/her to refer to Candis Cayne throughout her life.--> {{Infobox person | name = Candis Cayne | image = Candis_Cayne_2009.jpg | caption = Candis Cayne at the sixth annual Style Awards in Beverly Hills, California (October 10, 2009) | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1971|8|29}} | birth_place = [[Maui]], Hawaii, U.S.<ref>Wiseman, Eva. [https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2008/mar/09/5 Candis Payne: This California girl is the first transsexual to star in a prime-time soap], ''The Guardian'', March 9, 2008. Retrieved February 1, 2010.</ref> | occupation = Actress, performance artist | years_active = 1995–present | spouse = | partner = Marco McDermott (2002–2010) | website = {{URL|http://www.candiscayne.com}} }} '''Candis Cayne'''<ref name=KITV>{{cite web|title=Sultry Blond On ABC Show Is Hawaii Transgender |publisher=KITV.com |date=November 15, 2007 |url=http://www.kitv.com/news/14606991/detail.html |accessdate=January 15, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723124439/http://www.kitv.com/news/14606991/detail.html |archivedate=July 23, 2011 }}</ref> (born August 29, 1971) is an American actress and [[performance art]]ist.
Cayne was known to perform in New York City nightclubs in [[drag queen|drag]] since the 1990s,<ref name="NYT 2004">{{cite news| last=Piepenburg |first=Eric |date=November 6, 2004 |title=Keep Your Eye on the Road (If You Can)|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/06/nyregion/keep-your-eye-on-the-road-if-you-can.html?sec=health&pagewanted=1|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> and came out as a woman in 1996; Cayne came to national attention in 2007 for portraying [[transgender]] mistress Carmelita on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s prime time drama ''[[Dirty Sexy Money]]''.<ref name="October Surprises">{{cite web |last=Brownworth | first=Victoria A. | title=October Surprises | work=[[Bay Area Reporter]]| date=October 18, 2007 | url =http://ebar.com/arts/art_article.php?sec=lavendertube&article=49 | accessdate=October 20, 2007}}</ref><ref name="Advocate 2009-03">{{cite news|title=I Advocate ...|date=March 2009|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|publisher=Issue #1024|pages=80}}</ref><ref name="Metro UK 2008-03-13">{{cite web|publisher=Metro.co.uk|date=March 13, 2008|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/fame/article.html?in_article_id=117834&in_page_id=7&expand=true |title=Transsexual beauty makes TV history|accessdate=February 20, 2009}}</ref> The role makes Cayne the first transgender actress to play a recurring transgender character in primetime.<ref name="October Surprises"/><ref name="Advocate 2009-03"/><ref name="Metro UK 2008-03-13"/><ref>{{cite news|title=21 Transgender People Who Influenced American Culture| url=http://time.com/130734/transgender-celebrities-actors-athletes-in-america/|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]].com | date=May 29, 2014}}</ref>
==Early life== Candis Cayne was born Brendan McDaniel<ref>CBS News,[https://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/transgender-celebrities-you-need-to-know/16/ "Transgender celebs you need to know"]</ref> in 1971<ref name=KITV/> on [[Maui]], Hawaii. She has a fraternal twin brother named Dylan. Their parents taught at a [[Waldorf education|Waldorf School]], and the family lived on campus.<ref name="venus">Venus, Michael (2002). Michael Venus Profiles: Candis Cayne. ''YouTube''</ref> She graduated from [[Henry Perrine Baldwin High School]] in 1989<ref name=KITV /> and then spent a year in Los Angeles, where she trained as a dancer.<ref name="NYT 2004"/>
==Career== Cayne then moved to New York in the early 1990s, making a name for herself as a choreographer and [[drag queen|drag performer]].<ref name="NYT 2004"/> About three years after her arrival in NYC, Cayne realized that the term [[transgender]] described how she felt about herself.<ref name="NYT 2004"/> Already performing as "Candis Cayne" at New York [[gay bar]] Boy Bar and as a featured performer at Tour in New York's Chelsea, the entertainer also participated in [[Wigstock]], the annual [[Drag (clothing)|drag]] festival in Manhattan's [[East Village, Manhattan|East Village]]. In 1995 Cayne appeared in the related documentary film ''[[Wigstock: The Movie]]'', the comedy-drama film ''[[Stonewall (1995 film)|Stonewall]]'', and the [[Universal Studios]] comedy feature film ''[[To Wong Foo, Thanks for Everything! Julie Newmar]]'', for which she also did choreography.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0147307/|title=Candis Cayne - IMDb|last=|first=|date=1998-2018|website=IMBd|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=January 17, 2018}}</ref>
In 1996, she had a supporting role in the comedy-drama film ''Always Something Better'' (a.k.a. ''Never Look Back'').<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0251896 |title=Always Something Better (1996) |publisher=Internet Movie Database |accessdate=June 17, 2012}}</ref> In 1997 Cayne was in a documentary called Drag Time on HBO along with many other famous New York nightlife performers. Candis also co-starred in the music video for [[RuPaul]]'s "[[A Little Bit of Love (RuPaul song)|A Little Bit of Love]]" with [[Drag queen|female impersonator]] [[Jazzmun]]. Cayne also starred as the title character in the 1998 independent film ''[[Mob Queen]]'', and won the 2001 [[Miss Continental]] pageant.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thebatonshowlounge.com/continental_20011.htm |title=Miss Continental 2001 |publisher=TheBatonShowLounge.com |accessdate=February 20, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20011212062801/http://www.thebatonshowlounge.com/continental_20011.htm# |archive-date=December 12, 2001 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vickirene.net/mcont.htm |title=Miss Continental Pageant Throughout the Years |publisher=Vickirene.net |accessdate=February 20, 2009}}</ref> In 2007 Cayne was cast as Annaka Manners in the 2007 RuPaul film ''[[Starrbooty]]''.
From 2007 to 2008 Cayne played Carmelita Rainer, a [[trans woman]] having an affair with married New York Attorney General Patrick Darling (played by [[William Baldwin]]), on the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] prime time drama ''[[Dirty Sexy Money]]''.<ref name="October Surprises"/><ref name="Advocate 2009-03"/><ref name="Metro UK 2008-03-13"/> She had a recurring role as the transgender character Alexis Stone in season six of ''[[Nip/Tuck]]''.<ref>[[Nip/Tuck (season 6)|''Nip/Tuck'', Season 6]]</ref> Cayne has appeared as a judge and Dean of Dance on ''[[RuPaul's Drag U]]''. As a dance teacher, she taught contestants original choreography to "[[No Scrubs]]" by [[TLC (band)|TLC]] and [[Kelis]]'s song "[[Milkshake (song)|Milkshake]]". In 2011, she guest-starred on the TV show ''[[Necessary Roughness (TV series)|Necessary Roughness]]'' as Geraldine.
In 2015, Cayne started making appearances in seasons 1 and 2 of [[Caitlyn Jenner]]'s reality show ''[[I Am Cait]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-i-am-cait-recap-20150803-story.html#page=1|title='I Am Cait' recap: It's all fun and games until someone calls you oblivious|author=Christie D'Zurilla|date=August 3, 2015|publisher = [[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=2015-08-03}}</ref>
==Activism and personal life==
Cayne began [[Transitioning (transgender)|transitioning]] circa 1996.<ref name=KITV />
Cayne has stated, "I'm not trying to be a spokeswoman for the transgender community; I just want to be looked at as a living, breathing, happy human being."<ref name="Advocate 2009-03"/> She calls the [[LGBT]] community "the last great minority" and supports the [[Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation]].<ref name="Advocate 2009-03"/>
In August 2015 Candis Cayne teamed up with the global LGBT social network [[Moovz|MOOVZ]] as the new global creative director.<ref>{{Cite web|title = What Is Caitlyn Jenner's Friend Candis Cayne Working on Next?|url = http://www.people.com/article/caitlyn-jenner-friend-candis-cayne-teams-up-lgbt-app-moovz|accessdate = 2015-08-09}}</ref>
For over eight years, ending in 2010, Cayne was in a relationship with DJ Marco McDermott, to whom she referred as her husband.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://people.com/archive/dirty-sexy-moneys-candis-cayne-vol-68-no-19/|title=Dirty Sexy Money’s Candis Cayne – Vol. 68 No. 19|date=2007-11-05|newspaper=PEOPLE.com|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Caitlyn Jenner Rumored To Be Dating Trans Actress Candis Cayne|url = http://www.newnownext.com/caitlyn-jenner-rumored-to-be-dating-trans-actress-candis-cayne/07/2015/|accessdate = 2015-08-24}}</ref> During that time, she helped raise McDermott's daughter, Satori, from a previous relationship.
In 2016, during season 2 of the reality show ''[[I Am Cait]]'', Cayne explored the possibility of [[Adoption|adopting]] as a single parent.

The game involves managing a coffee business by buying new stores, recipes & advertisements. A '''Control Loading System''' ('''CLS''', also known as '''Electric Control Loading'''), is used to provide pilots with realistic [[flight control]] forces in a [[flight simulator]] or training device. These are used in both commercial and military training applications.
== History ==
The history of control loading systems starts with the history of flight simulation. The first flight simulator was the [[Link Trainer]], also known as the Blue Box. This was developed in the 1920s and used pumps, valves and bellows to provide the flight control forces. The next development in control loading systems was the use of [[hydraulic actuators]] to provide the forces required on the flight controls. These were utilized for around 20 years in the simulator industry until the development of [[electric actuators]].
== Control Loading Systems ==
=== Design and Technology === The main concept is to provide forces to the pilot using an actuator (hydraulic or electric). The approach used in high fidelity applications is to connect this actuator via a linkage to the pilot controls. The actuator is then controlled with a servo controller to control the torque or current of the motor. An outer-loop control then controls the torque provided to the pilot using a control loop around a force sensor.
The control loading system must take in inputs from the simulator and pilot and provide outputs for the pilot and simulator. Inputs are application of force and aircraft states and outputs are flight control position and forces. An aircraft with reversible controls needs to have all of the complex components modeled within the control loading system. These include cables, rods, aero forces from the control surface, centering springs and trim actuators. As the control system gets more complicated they have to simulate effects such as bob-weights and feel units. [[Fly-by-wire]] systems are disconnected from the control surfaces and so do not need the complex features but add other functionality which is simulated. The high fidelity architecture has centralized control, individual analog signals to the control module, a brushless DC motor with low gear ratio and linkages to the pilot controls. The modular designs have localized control and digital reporting over a [[field bus]] to the central control module. The control loading systems are designed to allow situating the actuators closer to the pilot. This is necessary for mission training systems<ref name="RAeS Paper">{{cite web|url=http://www.wittenstein-us.com/tech-support/resources/documents/Control_Loading_for_Mission_Training_Devices.pdf|title=Control Loading System Developments related to Mission Training Systems |accessdate=2009-05-04}}</ref> that can be easily deployed and moved around the world.
Control Loading Systems are similar in design to active sidesticks. These provide cues to pilots during the flight via actuation systems. Some examples of active sidesticks used in aircraft are for the [[F-35 Lightning II]] and the [[T-50 Golden Eagle]] jet trainer developed by KAI in partnership with Lockheed Martin Corporation.
=== Standards and Regulations === The regulations governing control loading systems for civil simulators are the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] regulations in North America and EASA (formerly JAA) in Europe. The FAA documents are AC 120-40B for airplane simulator qualification, Advisory circular 120-45A for Airplane Flight Training Device Qualification and AC 120-63 for helicopter Simulator Qualification. The EASA regulations are similar to the FAR's. Between 2006 and 2008 the International Working Group<ref name="RAeS IWG">{{cite web|url=http://www.raes-fsg.org.uk/|title=Royal Aeronautical Society Flight simulation Group Webpage |accessdate=2009-05-04}}</ref> of the RAeS's Flight Simulation Group met on several occasions to redefine the standards applicable to flight simulation. This resulted in the release of a draft standards document to [[ICAO]]. This will be released by ICAO in 2009 and at this time the FAA and EASA should incorporate this into the regulations. The changes behind the standards will define different levels of simulator training devices which define what training requirements can be trained on with particular levels of simulators.
== References ==
